text: hi everyone Anthony Fantino here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for review of the new pseudo
record anchor zoom Udo is the musical
project of songwriter and musical sonic
tinkerer Nick Muto formerly known as
being one half of the experimental music
duo of B books the books to me a very
important musical project that fused
together elements of folk music
singer-songwriter music rock electronics
as well as a very eclectic array of
vocal samples across their discography
their final LP before they disbanded the
way out is easily one of my favorite
records in their discography and this is
their debut album as well which is great
too
now before disbanding the books Nixon
Muto had put out music under these a
Muto name before but once the books were
kaput he came back under this name but
kind of reforms Muto as sort of being
like a full band as opposed to just a
small-scale musical project that
featured still a lot of ambient tracks a
lot of experimental tracks and this
self-titled record that zmuda returned
with was a pretty nice straightforward
LP it wasn't quite as difficult or as
experimental as the books previous album
but I still think Nick lived up to his
pretty adventurous reputation fusing
together elements of acoustic and
electronic music along with rock and for
all of his odd musical quirks Nick was
usually pretty good at bringing things
back down to earth and coming together
with a pretty coherent enjoyable song
with a bit of a pop appeal now with this
new and sort of sophomore record right
here anchor there are two things that
are pretty apparent the imagery that
comes together with a record titled
anchor something that holds you in place
keeps you grounded and Nick is
definitely doing that on here on this
sequel album where he isn't really
wandering too far outside of the sound
profile that he introduced on his
previous record and my first impression
of this album cover and the first track
off of this record itself is that this
is kind of a winter album it is slow it
is frosty it's sort of quiet it's
it really kind of feels like just the
the stillness that you feel when you go
outside when you get that first huge
winter blizzard and the very next
morning you're going out and everything
just seems totally frozen and quiet this
opener that I'm talking about is titled
good graces and on this song we're
getting Nick's typically very young
boyish voice singing very gently over
these very serene synth escapes there's
a very icy sheen on these tracks some
very brooding electric piano and bass
come and lay down the line and a lot of
tracks here follow suit in this mood
this album is definitely a mood change
in a pretty big way
there's the song Henry Lee which is sort
of a take on a traditional track that
features a lot of very Airy ethereal
blizzards of synth arpeggios swirling
around Nick's voice and then there's
tracks on here like the great equator
which are a little more lively in the
second half musically for the first half
it's a bit of a slow thaw but then Nick
introduces a bunch of glitchy off-kilter
sort of sporadic synthesizer melodies
that really heat the track up this
record for sure relies much more on
subtlety and melody in comparison with
the last Mutoh album and it's not a road
I'm really sure I'm crazy to hear Nick
zoom Udo move down because I'm not
hearing a whole lot of finesse on this
record in my opinion not a whole lot of
fluidity instead I'm hearing a lot of
beats and a lot of since sequences that
feel just so lock in step and
methodically put together and I don't
mind this characteristic of zoom Udo's
music it's what really attracted me to
his last full-length LP but I'm not
really sure it translates to the slow
burning beauty I feel like he's trying
to conjure on this latest LP of his
fully anyway it does a little bit on
some tracks I definitely love the song
stinker one of the best tracks off this
entire LP and one of the quietest to has
these beautiful waves of synthesizers
just coming again and again and again
they have a nice sheen on them and
Nick's voice in these waves of synths
sounds really broken dreary just oh
there's just a really painful emotion
that's just so
palpable on this track it's difficult to
describe but for every patient in vast
song that is on this record that I enjoy
there's another that really doesn't do
much to move me emotionally really sort
of blobby faint and listless tracks so
you stopped counting and there are some
other tracks on here that I find to be
engaging too but they have somewhat
abrupt endings that kind of kill the
song just a tad for me the track needs
some Sun which may also play into the
winter theme of this album the song
hegemony as well as the track io which
is one of the album's just Poppaea stand
most upbeat tracks it's got an awesome
melody I love the black Brant synth
tones on this track - really crunchy
drums this track sounds like a new wave
song with an engineering degree from MIT
to me overall this is a decent follow up
to the last Mutoh LP it's a nice sister
album I'm kind of hoping that Nick's
next full-length will have a few more
surprises in it and maybe it's just the
time of year that isn't really totally
vibing with me on this record this could
most definitely be your perfect winter
album several months from now maybe a
wintry mood is what I really need to get
into this album but as of right now even
though there are quite a few tracks that
I like it's the sort of abrupt endings
and the handful of a very forgettable
unengaging soundscape like tracks that
have left me just somewhat on the fence
with this thing I'm feeling a light
decent six on the cell P transition if
you've given this album a listen what
did you think of it did you love it did
you hate it why what do you think I
should review next and that is fact
Anthony Fantana zoom Ito forever
